1 Introduction Graphene has been considered as the promising candidate material of optoelectronic or biomedical applications for the next generation due to the high electronic mobility (2.5×105 cm2 V−1 s−1 at room temperature) [1], high thermal conductivity (>3000WmK−1) [2], high capability to sustain high electric current densities (106 times higher than copper) [3], high specific surface area (2360m2/g of a single graphene sheet) [4], extraordinary tensile elasticity (∼1TPa) [5], high intrinsic strength (∼130GP) [6], complete impermeability to any gases [7], and outstanding optical transmittance (∼97.7%) [8,9].
Since a single layer graphene can reach ultraviolet–visible light transmittance up to 97.7% theoretically, the more carbon atomic layers, the lower the light transmittance.

The significance of this work is as follows: (1) poly(SBMA-co-IA) coating has excellent anti-fogging and frost-resisting properties, and can maintain high light transmittance (95%) even under strong fog and frost conditions [43].

After fogging, we can find that the transmittance of bare glass and SBMA coated glass have dropped to 75% and 82.5%, while the transmittance of the poly(SBMA-co-IA) coated glass slide is still above 95%, which proves that the coating has excellent anti-fogging ability for fog drops (Fig. 5(c)).
The poly(SBMA-co-IA) can spread evenly on the surface of transparent optical materials, so the coating surface is very smooth and the transmittance that after fogging test can reach 95%.
